title: Digital Product Design Fundamentals
description: Check how well you know modern design tools and practices—from Adobe XD, Figma, and Sketch to usability testing, typography, and prototyping workflows.

questions.question: In Figma, which keyboard shortcut instantly duplicates the currently selected layer or frame?
questions.explanation: Pressing Ctrl (Windows) or Cmd (macOS) + D creates an exact copy in place while preserving the selection.

questions.question: What is the former name Adobe XD used for what are now called Components?
questions.explanation: Adobe XD originally called reusable design elements “Symbols” before aligning the term with other tools as “Components.”

questions.question: Files created with Sketch are saved using which extension?
questions.explanation: Sketch documents use the proprietary .sketch extension, essentially a zipped-up JSON package.

questions.question: Adobe XD’s Repeat Grid feature is primarily used to:
options: Generate repeating lists or galleries from one base cell
Switch between design and prototype modes
questions.explanation: Repeat Grid lets you drag to duplicate a cell horizontally and/or vertically while keeping spacing and content in sync.

questions.question: Which panel in Figma provides developers with CSS, iOS, and Android code snippets and allows direct asset download for hand-off?
questions.explanation: The Inspect panel exposes measurements, tokens, and export settings needed during developer hand-off.

questions.question: For vector icons destined for web use, which file format preserves scalability and small file size while remaining text-based?
questions.explanation: Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG) is an XML-based format that scales without pixelation and can be styled with CSS.

questions.question: In typography, the vertical distance from the baseline to the top of lowercase letters such as “x” is called the:
questions.explanation: X-height influences legibility and perceived font size, especially in UI labels.

questions.question: Which principle of visual hierarchy most directly guides the viewer’s eye by using size differences?
questions.explanation: Contrast—through scale, weight, or color—creates focal points and clarifies information priority.

questions.question: Low-fidelity wireframes are typically produced to:
options: Validate layout concepts rapidly before heavy styling
Hand off spacing specs to developers
questions.explanation: Early wireframes focus on structure and flow, minimizing time invested before stakeholder alignment.

questions.question: During moderated usability testing, the facilitator’s primary responsibility is to:
options: Guide participants but avoid leading them, asking clarifying questions after tasks
Silently observe without interacting at all
Explain the correct actions whenever the user hesitates
Write code fixes in real time
questions.explanation: Moderators encourage think-aloud feedback and ensure tasks are completed while keeping bias minimal.

questions.question: In Figma, Auto Layout is especially useful for:
options: Building adaptive buttons, lists, and components that resize with content
questions.explanation: Auto Layout lets frames adjust padding, direction, and spacing automatically when content changes.

questions.question: Which Sketch feature groups color, text, and effect presets so they can be reused across documents and shared in a team library?
questions.explanation: Shared Styles centralize design tokens—updating the style updates every linked layer.

questions.question: A user flow diagram primarily illustrates:
options: The detailed pixel grid of each screen
How users move step-by-step through tasks to reach a goal
Every possible keyboard shortcut in the product
questions.explanation: User flows map decision points and screens, clarifying IA and revealing friction in journeys.

questions.question: Information Architecture (IA) in digital design focuses on:
options: Structuring and labeling content so people can find and understand it
questions.explanation: IA deals with taxonomy, navigation, and content organization to support findability and usability.

questions.question: Which prototyping approach allows designers to define micro-interactions like button hover states without writing code inside Adobe XD?
questions.explanation: Component States enable toggling between default, hover, and active visuals to simulate interactive feedback.

questions.question: During asset handoff, providing a baseline grid and spacing values helps developers primarily with:
questions.explanation: Clear spacing tokens prevent subjective guesses and enforce the design system’s rhythm in code.

questions.question: Vector boolean operations such as Union, Subtract, Intersect, and Exclude are essential when:
options: Combining multiple paths to craft a complex icon shape
questions.explanation: Boolean ops merge or cut paths, letting you refine icons or illustrations while maintaining editability.

questions.question: Which Figma feature lets multiple designers collaborate in real time on the same file without version-conflict merges?
questions.explanation: Each collaborator’s cursor appears live, enabling synchronous editing akin to Google Docs for design.

questions.question: The ideal minimum number of participants recommended by Nielsen Norman Group for catching the majority of usability issues in a single round of testing is:
questions.explanation: NN/g studies show that about five users uncover 80 % of problems, balancing insight with test cost.

questions.question: When refining visual hierarchy, which CSS property would you most likely adjust to make headline text dominate body copy on a web page?
questions.explanation: Increasing font-weight (e.g., bold) elevates prominence, signaling importance within the hierarchy.
